messages.message: I’ve been reviewing the updated test videos for high-traffic zones. The jitter in bounding boxes is more apparent during peak hours.

replies.message: Thanks, Maria. Do you think tweaking the Kalman filter parameters would help reduce this?
It’s worth testing. I’ve uploaded a few reference frames to Notion: https://notion.nvidia.com/retail-safety/bounding-box-analysis.
I’ll take a look, Maria. We should also document these cases in Confluence to track changes.
Good call. Let’s keep the documentation comprehensive. @arjun.mehta, let’s sync tomorrow on parameter adjustments.

messages.message: I’ve added a section in the experimental results page to track bounding box jitter cases: https://notion.nvidia.com/retail-safety/experimental-results.

replies.message: Thanks, Priya. I’ll add additional notes based on what I see in the video analysis.
Should we involve the QA team to validate these updates in simulated environments before deployment?
That makes sense. I’ll reach out to QA and schedule a review session next week.

messages.message: In the meantime, I’ve started a thread on Confluence about fallback mechanisms for Dallas deployment: https://confluence.nvidia.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=123789.

replies.message: Great! I’ll review the thread and add my inputs about anomaly detection edge cases.
Quick update: The feedback loop for anomaly detection seems to have improved latency metrics. I’ll include this in my weekly update.
That’s great news. I’ll ensure this gets highlighted in our next meeting with stakeholders.

messages.message: Do we have a timeline for completing the fallback mechanism tests for Dallas?

replies.message: If all goes well, we should have initial results by mid-next week.
Let’s aim to wrap this up by Friday. QA validation will be crucial here.
Agreed. I’ll coordinate with QA to keep them in the loop.

messages.message: Just FYI, I’ve started an internal discussion on Slack about improving anomaly overlays for better user comprehension.

replies.message: Sounds interesting. Tag me in that discussion, please.
Done. Let’s see if the UX team can contribute ideas to this as well.

messages.message: Do we have any insights on why edge device optimization is causing discrepancies between test environments?

replies.message: Still investigating. It might be related to hardware-specific inference behavior.
Can we compare this with the performance logs from the previous deployment?
I’ll pull those logs and share them for analysis.
Thanks, James. That should help narrow down the cause.
